summary: openhim mapping mediator nodered evaluation spike
description: openhim mediators can be developed in any language and only talk to the openhim via its restful api
they do not have to be installed on the same server as the openhim
the only restriction is that a mediator must communicate with the openhim core in a particular way

in order to support centralized management of mediators in the openhim console mediators must register themselves with the openhim core accept requests from the openhim core and return a specialised response to the openhim core to explain what that mediator did

the mapping mediator discussed in this paper would need to comply with the general requirements of openhim mediators and should ensure that the mediator is able to reach the servers restful api endpoint
the openhim is able to reach the mediators endpoint for receiving requests
the mediator is configured with the correct credentials so that it may access the openhims restful api as an admin user
the mediator trusts the openhim cores certificate as all api communication takes place over https

the mapping mediator does not need to fulfil functionality offered by the openhim core and console such as transaction and error management and the configuration/management of clients channels and routes

the mapping mediator is primarily concerned with simplifying the task and complexity of configuring message format adaptation and then orchestration between hie components services and point of service applications as well as the potential for easier management of workflows and interactions between mediators
of the objectives dont need to fully implemented if theres no time were just looking for a clearer sense of whether the objectives be met
goals document how to get it installed getting started

summary: content is being but original header remains
description: when the him gets a compressed response it decompresses it and then it and forwards
however it keeps the original header so if the compression ratio is different to the original the response can be truncated
the him needs to set the header to the new value when happens
ideally the him would just decompress for the transaction log and pass through the original response rather than using resources to compress again

description: integration tests are using callbacks for async and should use async await instead

summary: unit test upgrade
description: unit tests use callbacks for asynchronous tests
change to async await

summary: remove shared resources with tests
description: currently when the tests fire they share resources for example the instance they are testing db it's working and the faked tcp servers
when a test breaks it can break unrelated tests
this will also reduce the amount and reliance on buggy cleanup code

summary: as an administrator i need a way to remove bodies from transactions after a certain period of time
description: the bodies of transactions can contain sensitive personal information
there needs to be a way to remove the bodies from transactions after a certain period of time in order to comply with privacy requirements
ideally this should happen automatically after a configurable period of time
this allows transactions to be investigated and replayed within a window period
after this the bodies should be removed but the rest of the transaction details should remain

summary: remove ensureindex call when saving events from core
description: performance testing uncovered that multiple ensureindex calls are being done on the events collection per transaction
this should be done once when the application starts up instead of on every call
some investigation needs to be done to decide on the best approach with mongoose before this is implemented
see

summary: core crashes with memory leak
description: info job auto retry failed transactions has completed info starting job generate transaction alerts last ran at wed jun utc info starting job auto retry failed transactions last ran at wed jun utc debug executing query autoretry.findandremove and channelid requesttimestamp lte debug alerting task total time ms info job generate transaction alerts has completed debug auto retry task total time ms info job auto retry failed transactions has completed info api request made by from has expired denying access debug processed internal audit info starting job generate transaction alerts last ran at wed jun utc info starting job auto retry failed transactions last ran at wed jun utc debug executing query autoretry.findandremove and channelid requesttimestamp lte debug alerting task total time ms info job generate transaction alerts has completed debug auto retry task total time ms info job auto retry failed transactions has completed fatal error allocation failed javascript heap out of memory last few gcs ms mb ms allocation failure gc in old space last resort js stacktrace js stack trace security context js object defer undefined then an object with map js function s sharedfunctioninfo js function t const char const bool warn master worker died info master worker with pid is online the options are deprecated all their options are supported at the top level of the options object the options are deprecated all their options are supported at the top level of the options object info starting openhim server on info started rerun task processor info auditing udp server listening on port info http listening on port info auditing tcp server listening on port

summary: missing indexes for the basic transaction log filters
description: with a large number of transactions in the database the transaction log in the console becomes unusable and trying to use it causes throughput in the core to drop off
by using the mongodb query profiler i found that there was a missing index on parentid and a missing compound index on channelid and request timestamp
by adding these the transaction log becomes fairly usable again as long as no advanced filters are used

summary: large rerun batches cause massive cpu load
description: medscheme issue rerunning transactions in large batches causes the cpu usage to increase dramatically which results in reduced throughput in the openhim

rerunning batches of causes the openhim to almost grind to a halt and the processing is extremely slow transactions rerun over smaller batches of transactions and a batch size of still increase the cpu usage a lot but don't cause the same issues as the larger batches
the openhim needs to be smarter about how it handles large batches or the maximum batch size needs to be reduced

summary: the dashboard becomes unusable under load
description: medscheme the dashboard uses aggregation queries to calculate the number of transactions and the average response time
when there is a large number of transactions in the date range then this aggregation becomes extremely slow and the dashboard stops working
this issue is exaggerated by the repeated requests that the dashboard makes to keep up to date
a possible solution would be to have a separate collection to be used for the dashboard metrics and use increment operators to update the documents in this collection efficiently

summary: per channel timeouts
description: when a new timeout is set we would need to make sure that timeout is set for outbound requests and then broadcast an event to that each cluster node picks up and check if the timeout being set is greater than the current on if so we need to set the timeout to the greater value plus some buffer we also need to set the server timeout to the longest channel timeout buffer on startup

summary: write scripts to set up a performance testing environment for the openhim
description: in order to acturately measure performance a pristine testing environment is needed for each test run

this must include importing a baseline set of data so that the tests produce consistent results between runs

summary: filter transaction log by time
description: user story as a transaction monitoring user i would like to filter transaction log by time and date instead of just date so that i can more easily locate a particular set of transaction around a specific time acceptance criteria given a list of transactions when the list is viewed then the user should be able to add a time component to the current start and end date fields given a list of transactions when the user sets a start date then if they don't set a time component it should default to midnight on the start date given a list of transactions when the user sets a end date then if they don't set a time component it should default to the last millsecond of the end date
